div.p: Illustrated literary annual. The first four volumes, 1824–27, were published by Lupton Relfe. Another seventeen volumes, for the years 1828–44 (i.e., published “for” the New Yearʼs holiday seasons 1828–44, the volumes themselves produced and released late in the previous year, 1827–43), were published by Smith, Elder & Company (Harris, Forget Me Not, 124–26, 323–34; Faxon, Literary Annuals, 93–95). While not the first publication to sponsor Ruskinʼs writing, Friendshipʼs Offering was the first widely distributed venue for his poetry, beginning with “Saltzburg” and “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, included in the volume for 1835 (released in October or November 1834). Thereafter, Friendshipʼs Offering remained a reliable showcase for Ruskinʼs verse, which appeared in each annual volume until the seriesʼ demise.
See also Annuals and Other Illustrated Books; Samuel Rogers: The Publication History of Rogersʼs Italy.

div.head: The Founding of the Annual by Lupton Relfe
div.p: The first volume of Friendshipʼs Offering appeared with the date 1824, published by a bookseller in Cornhill Street, Lupton Relfe. The Ruskin family had some awareness of this early stage of the annual, since the volume for 1825, Relfeʼs second volume in the series, entered the family library with an inscription to Mary Richardson (1815–49), Ruskinʼs cousin who first came to Camberwell to live with the family in 1827 (Dearden, Library of John Ruskin, 122 [no. 953]; and for specific features of the 1825 Friendshipʼs Offering, see Harris, “Feminizing the Textual Body”, 601–2, 611).

div.head: Searching for a Niche
div.p: As Katherine D. Harris remarks, Relfeʼs first volume, for 1824, appeared only one year after the very first of the British annuals, Forget Me Not (1823), was released by the firm of Rudolf Ackermann in 1822 for the holiday season of 1822–23. Harris transcribes the preface of this debut volume of Friendshipʼs Offering and details the volumeʼs contents, revealing a derivative and miscellaneous assemblage that exposes Relfe as aspiring only to mimic and capitalize on Ackermannʼs achievement. He had formed no distinctive conception of his production, which mixes features of the German literary annual, on which Ackermann modeled Forget Me Not, with traditional elements of the English eighteenth‐century almanac and “pocket book” (Harris, Forget Me Not, 124–25, 280; see also Annuals and Other Illustrated Books).

Relfeʼs inclusion of pocket‐book features such as blank diary pages did not necessarily suggest incoherence: as Sara Lodge has noted, during the post‐Waterloo period Leigh Hunt produced an item, the Literary Pocket‐Book (1818–22), which invited the consumer to inscribe poetic effusions on a blank "“Calendar of Nature”, thus activating the reader to put literary response to use in constructing, as Hunt put it, “a sort of Court Calendar” of oneʼs own (Lodge, “Romantic Reliquaries”, 25). Nonetheless, Relfe initially seems to have had trouble positioning his annual to respond to the conflicting audience demands of the transitional, post‐Waterloo period. In 1858, when the history of the annuals began to be written following their decline in popularity, an article in the Bookseller settled on the opinion that Relfeʼs Friendshipʼs Offering was characterized by an “unpromising” mix of “ruled pages for memoranda” with “indifferent views of Continental cities”, “poor verses”, and the occasional “tale by Mrs. Opie” (i.e., Amelia Opie [1769–1853]) (“The Annuals of Former Days”, 496).

According to the Bookseller article, the fortunes of Friendshipʼs Offering were turned around by by the editorship of T. K. Hervey (1799–1859). In his prefatory remarks for Relfeʼs 1826 volume, Hervey did announce “a view to an entire change in . . . [the annualʼs] character and plan”, shifting emphasis from the transience of an annual to the permanence of a keepsake: the “alterations” were to “consist in the removal of all those features which marked it as more peculiarly adapted for one season of the year than another” (directly echoing an 1825 Monthly Review article that praised British annuals over their Continental precursors for “exclud[ing] every feature which would seem to attach them to one year more than to another” [Unsigned review of Literary Souvenir (1825), 279]; see also Annuals and Other Illustrated Books: The Character and Reception of the Annuals). Instead, Friendshipʼs Offering would become a more permanent, treasurable item, “combining, with the increased beauty of its embellishments, a high literary character” (Hervey, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1826], vi). Thus, according to Harris, the pocket‐book features of Relfeʼs earlier volumes such as blank calendar pages, informational charts, and even notated music fell away (Harris, Forget Me Not, 126); and while these earlier “album‐like qualities” did have the merit of allowing the giver and the recipient to personalize the volume with their own inscriptions, a “more marketable” item emerged for the period, one that required the annual to became a “completely prefabricated book of printed memories” (Harris, “Feminizing the Textual Body”, 607).

div.head: The Hervey Editorship: Improving the Literary Character
div.p: What signaled the improved “literary character” promised by Hervey? As star material for the 1826 volume, Maria Edgeworth (1769–1849) supplied an essay by her father, Richard Lovell Edgeworth (1744–1817); Washington Irving (1783–1859) and Lady Caroline Lamb (1785–1828) released scraps of verse by Lord Byron (1788–1824); and juvenilia were recovered by James Thomson (1700–1748). Otherwise, the roster of contributors for the 1826 volume proved similar to those for 1827. One or both volumes included poet/churchmen such as the Reverend Thomas Dale (1797–1870), Ruskinʼs future Camberwell schoolmaster, and the Reverend George Croly (1780–1860), Ruskinʼs future mentor. This class of writers also included the Reverend John Moultrie (1799–1874), the Rugby rector; and James Montgomery (1771–1854), the hymn writer. Among “poetesses” appeared L.E.L. (Letitia Landon, 1802–38) and—a poetess especially favored in the Ruskin household—Felicia Hemans (1793–1835). Among women writers of tales and sketches appeared Mary Russell Mitford (1787–1855) and Emma Roberts (1791–1840).

These and other contributors to the 1826 and 1827 volumes of Friendshipʼs Offering were, as reviewers commented, almost invariable presences in other annuals, as well—writers who supplied mainly verse, but who could also be relied on for a variety of commissions: Bernard Barton (1784–1849), John Clare (1793–1864), Allan Cunningham (1784–1842), Hervey, William Jerdan (1782–1869), Henry Neele (1798–1828), D. Lester Richardson (1801–65), and the translator John Bowring (1792–1872). Relief from the sentiments of such verse came from humorists like John Galt (1779–1839), Thomas Hood (1799–1845), and Horace Smith (1779–1849). Many of these contributors themselves labored as editors of other annuals, magazines, and newspapers, including Ruskinʼs future personal editor, W. H. Harrison (1792–1878), who appeared the for the first time in the Friendshipʼs Offering for 1827.

Thus the “improved literary character” of Friendshipʼs Offering succeeded in rendering the volume more predictable. The Monthly Review commented about the 1826 volume: “Where the character of this volume so closely corresponds to that of the ‘[Literary] Souvenir’”, reviewed in a previous issue for that year, “our general remarks may apply to either” (Unsigned review of Friendshipʼs Offering [1826] and Janus [1826], 161). Regarding the following yearʼs volume, that journal judged the “prose matter . . . [to be] upon the whole, the best that we have seen in any of these annual volumes”, but “after three or four pieces from the pens of Miss Landon, Mrs. Hemans, the Rev. Mr. Dale, and Mr. Hervey, we find nothing in the shape of verse, that rises above mediocrity” (Unsigned review of Friendshipʼs Offering [1827], 87). The contributors represented cultures of England, Scotland, Wales, and Ireland, as well as lived experience from abroad, sometimes writing in dialect. They wrote from a variety of religious and ideological stances, though never so aggressively as to perturb the unifying script of friendship, sentiment, and memory.

When reviewers found little to distinguish Friendshipʼs Offering from other annuals, they turned to the “embellishments” of illustration for comparisons, usually considered overall to be to the disadvantage of Relfeʼs volume (see “Miscellaneous” [Unsigned review of Friendshipʼs Offering (1827)], 300; Unsigned review of Friendshipʼs Offering [1826] and Janus [1826], 161; Unsigned review of Friendshipʼs Offering [1827], 87). The annual was in fact typical of the period in highlighting the shared “poetry” of the Sister Arts (see Illustration: The Poetry of the Sister Arts in the Relfe Annual); and the 1826 volume stands out for its sampling of contemporary French art, but reviews at the time were mixed (see Illustration: A Reflection of the Contest between the British Picturesque Aesthetic and French Neoclassweicism in the 1826 Relfe Annual). The future success of Friendshipʼs Offering depended on finding a niche that made the annual distinctive in an increasingly crowded field, but without disturbing the superficially various yet predictable offering of memory and friendship.

div.head: The Takeover of the Annual by Smith, Elder, & Company
div.p: Relfeʼs final volume of Friendshipʼs Offering was for 1827 (presumably released in late 1826), edited by Hervey and B. E. Pote (“Editors and Publishers of British Literary Annuals, 1823–31”, in Harris, Forget Me Not, 324). In 1827, the publication was taken over by the relatively young stationery and bookselling firm of Smith, Elder, & Company, which had recently moved to no. 65 Cornhill, near Relfe.

By 1827, Smith, Elderʼs publishing ventures in engravings and aquatints were already ambitiously refined, but with the acquisition of Friendshipʼs Offering the company made a bid for an expanded share of the burgeoning illustrated book market. Under their custodianship, Friendshipʼs Offering gained a measure of distinction in the growing field of annuals, owing most immediately to its more striking material appeal. Sales rose, eventually peaking at ten thousand copies per year, assuring the fortunes of Smith, Elder as a publisher. (As a comparison, Ackermannʼs Forget Me Not in some years achieved twenty thousand. See the account of Smith, Elder, & Company in Bell, “Smith, George Murray [1824–1901]”, the DNB biography of the son of George Smith (1789–1846), who founded the firm along with Alexander Elder (1790–1876); see also Ford, Ackermann, 65.)

Smith, Elder released their first volume of the annual in time for the 1827–28 holiday season. The volume for 1828 was edited by Charles Knight (1791–1873), the future publisher for the Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge, who was then struggling to establish himself in London publishing. Slightly readjusting the balance that Hervey had tipped from annual to keepsake, the publisher expanded the subtitle from A Literary Album to acknowledge the season with A Literary Album, and Christmas and New Yearʼs Present; at the same time, the keepsake element was enhanced with redesign of the presentation plate, which, as the Monthly Review appreciated, in some annuals “scarcely allowed” space “for the names of the ‘donor’ and ‘donee’ . . . [b]ut here [gave] full room even for a verse or two of compliment” (Unsigned review of The Keepsake [1828], Friendshipʼs Offering [1828], and The Christmas Box [1828], 71). The most striking change in the immediate impression made by the annual was effected by its binding.

The reviewer for the Monthly Review was impressed by the quality of illustration in Smith, Elderʼs first volume, suggesting that the company had already earned its reputation for high‐quality art reproduction: the plates were “really very creditable to the publishers”, their “subjects . . . selected with great judgment” and “engraved in a chaste, artist‐like style” (Unsigned review of The Keepsake [1828]; Friendshipʼs Offering [1828]; and The Christmas‐Box [1828], 71; see “Made Expressly for the Work”: The Art Scene in the Smith, Elder Annual).

div.head: Charles Knight and the First Smith, Elder Volume
div.p: The London Magazine praised the 1828 Friendshipʼs Offering for its collective “cheerful gaiety”, identifying its contributors as “chiefly formed from a set known to the world as the writers of the Etonian, one of the best books ever written by young men, . . . their talents . . . of a calibre well adapted for an annual, brisk, painted, and polished”. The reviewer apparently referred to a short‐lived school magazine, the Etonian (1820–21), which Knight had published, and which strictly applied only to a handful of the 1828 annualʼs male contributors—the poet W. M. Praed (1802–39), who founded the Etonian, along with the Reverend John Moultrie (1799–1874). Perhaps the reviewer meant to characterize the model of friendship that informed the anthology, although another writer for the Monthly Review wanted to know who Moultrie was, and why the volume contained so many of his poems, “as bad as a dose of opium” (“The Annuals” [unsigned review of Friendshipʼs Offering (1828), The Winterʼs Wreath (1828), The Pledge of Friendship (1828), and The Christmas Box (1828)], 56; Unsigned review of The Keepsake [1828], Friendshipʼs Offering [1828], and The Christmas Box [1828], 72; and for expressions of collective schoolboy identification in Rugby and Eton magazines, including the Etonian, in relation to pedagogy and Romantic poetry, see Weaver, “‘A School‐Boyʼs Story’”).

If Knight took advantage of his connection with the Etonian “set”, the larger roster of contributors suggests that the editor and proprietors made a substantial investment in order to lure readers with celebrated names—Maria Edgeworth (1769–1849), Thomas de Quincey (1785–1859), and the poet laureate, Robert Southey (1774–1843) (“The Friendshipʼs Offering, for 1828” [advertisement]). For the illustration of this volume, which it seems likely that the proprietors managed, rather than Knight, see “Made Expressly for the Work”: The Art Scene in the Smith, Elder Annual.

div.head: The Pringle Editorship
div.p: Knight was succeeded by Thomas Pringle, who within five years would undertake editing of Ruskinʼs poetry and introduce him to the fashionable literary world as the author “J.R.” in the Friendshipʼs Offering for 1835 (see “Saltzburg”: Discussion). Apparently before this time, Pringle had become a regular dinner guest of the Ruskins at Herne Hill, though in what year is unknown; the acquaintance may have been struck as early as autumn 1829, the season of Pringleʼs second volume of Friendshipʼs Offering, when Ruskinʼs cousin, Charles Richardson, was employed as a shop boy for Smith, Elder (see also Annuals and Other Illustrated Books: The Annuals and the Ruskin Family).

div.head: Pringle and Scottishness
div.p: Pringle was a native Scot like John James Ruskin as well as the publishers of Friendshipʼs Offering, George Smith and Alexander Elder. When Pringle took over the editorship of the annual, he was recently returned from South Africa, where, with a party of other Scots, he had emigrated in search of opportunities in the Cape Colony, which Britain had acquired as a possession in the Congress of Vienna. He returned to England with disappointed hopes, but with exotic experience to be made into poetry as well as a passion for the abolitionist cause. It was doubtless his earlier literary connections in Edinburgh, however, with figures no less auspicious than Walter Scott, James Hogg, and others, that made him a welcome guest at Herne Hill.

Pringle brought to his first volume of Friendshipʼs Offering a noticeable Caledonian emphasis. Under Knight, the annual for 1828 featured a handful of Scottish contributors. Under Pringle, the volume for 1829 presented over thirty contributions by Scots—more than a third of the total—including such poems as “The Highland Hunterʼs Coronach”, “On Leaving Scotland”, and “Auld Joe Nicholsonʼs Bonny Nannie: A Sang”; and such tales as “The Covenanters: A Scottish Traditionary Tale”. Scottish landscapes are also prominent among the engravings (see Pringleʼs Scottish Landscapes.

The Scotch emphasis was given contrasting reception by some reviewers in North Britain and South Britain. The Edinburgh Literary Journal proudly highlighted two annuals for 1829—Friendshipʼs Offering and the Anniversary—that were “edited by Scotchmen” and showcased Scotch “names . . . shin[ing] most conspicuously in their tables of contents”. Of the two, the Anniversary stood out most prominently for making “peculiar claims on the people of Scotland”. Edited by the poet Allan Cunningham, and making its debut that year, the Anniversary presented what the reviewer admitted may be considered “an over degree of nationality” by “[o]ur Southern friends” (“The Annuals for 1829”, 5).

Some southern journals did object, like La Belle Assemblée, “that too many of the pieces” in Pringleʼs 1829 Friendshipʼs Offering “derive their origin north of the Tweed”, as well as presenting “somewhat too large proportion of what may be termed religious matter”, which “can seldom be amalgamated successfully with the lighter effusions of the Belles Lettres” (“The Annuals for 1829”, 197). Those two objections were connected more straightforwardly and stridently by the Monthly Review, which advised the Anniversary to rein in Scotch contributions since “a beautiful work of art” requires that “all the parts shall be in unison”; and without “mean[ing] to insinuate any dislike of the true Doric dialect, as it has been called, of Scotland”, the reviewer urged that “in every instance the current language of England . . . prevail in the literature of the Annuals” (Unsigned review of The Anniversary [1829], The Amulet [1829], The Juvenile Forget Me Not [1829], and The Juvenile Keepsake [1829], 527, 530). From the first emergence of the annuals, the Monthly had treated these publications as “ministers of taste” from the metropolis to the provinces, and from England to the empire, conveying a unifying standard of taste (see Annuals and Other Illustrated Books: The Character and Reception of the Annuals).

Historically, the Monthly Review historically set itself up as a gatekeeper not only of taste but also of prescriptive diction and grammar—a prescriptiveness that, from the journalʼs eighteenth‐century beginnings, had taken aim especially at Scottish dialect, and all the more keenly so if the reviewer was himself a Scot (Percy, “Periodical Reviews and the Rise of Prescriptivism”). The journal was also known for a longstanding prejudice against religious “enthusiasm”, an animus that, in the eighteenth century, was directed against Methodism (McInelly, “When Worlds Collide”). In 1829, the Monthly Review linked what it perceived as linguistic and religious parochialism in the Anniversary, singling out a contribution by the Church of Scotland clergyman, Edward Irving (1792–1834), which the reviewer characterized as given to a “‘puritanic . . . phraseology, which literary persons belonging to that sect are too much in the habit of using on all occasions”. In contrast, as an example of “neatly written essays on popular subjects”, reviewer quoted at length from another piece in the volume “on the Female Beauty of the Three Kingdoms”, which discovers ecumenically that female beauty is independent of nation, being found wherever “gentleness of . . . [womanʼs] nature and the kindliness of her heart throw a household halo around her person” (Unsigned review of The Anniversary (1829), The Amulet (1829), The Juvenile Forget Me Not (1829), and The Juvenile Keepsake (1829), 526, 528; and see M., “English, Scotch, and Irish Beauty”, in Cunningham, ed., The Anniversary, 201–5, 205).

Editors of annuals faced risks in presenting any perceivable excess that reviewers might argue as deranging the aesthetic that the Monthlyʼs reviewer characterized as a “beautiful . . . unison”. At the same time, reviewers complained routinely about the overall blandness and uniformity of the annuals, especially as the market grew increasingly competitive with new titles added each year (see the “Chronological Index of British and American Literary Annual Titles” in Harris, Forget Me Not, 280–85). Cunningham, or his publisher, ceased publication of the Anniversary in the midst of compiling only its second volume (Cunninghamʼs biographer blamed the publisherʼs unsettled plans [Hogg, Life of Allan Cunningham, 332]), but Pringle survived criticism of the lopsided Scottish contributions to Friendshipʼs Offering. Although recognized as “one of Scotlandʼs true tuneful sons” by Blackwoodʼs Edinburgh Magazine—the reviewer admitting that the Scotch emphasis that Pringle imparted to Friendshipʼs Offering (for 1830) brought out, “of all our critical qualities, nationality . . . [as] the chief” (#“Monologue”, 967)—Pringle himself avoided any such direct credit or imputation, claiming in his preface to the annual (for 1829) to have “promote[d] . . . a sound and liberal national taste”. Alongside the many pieces about Scotland, he took care to include an “Irish Tale”, “A German Legend”, a tale of “an old Frenchman of the time of Louis XIV”, and—in a broadly unifying spirit—an “Ode on the Death of Queen Charlotte” by Southey, the English poet laureate. In 1829, George IIIʼs queen had been dead for a decade, but her image retained its currency for the annuals in the same spirit with which the Monthly Review admired the Anniversaryʼs essay on the universality of female virtues: all “future Queens [shall] to her / As to their best exemplar look”, the poet predicted, since, thanks to Charlotte, “At Court, the Household Virtues had their place” (Pringle, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1829], vi, 191, 93, 56, 106–7; and for more on British nationalism in reviews of the annuals, see Forget Me Not, 211–14).

Perhaps as a result of these precautions, even the Monthly, for all its militancy for unifying the empire under English taste, could allow Pringle the compliment of exerting “the influence of an individual mind” over his annual. The reviewer did not refer to the annualʼs Caledonian flavor specifically but to a warmth that lives up to the annualʼs title—a “pervading spirit . . . of a deep and heart‐stirring benevolence; not wanting an occasional mixture of deeper passion, but for the most part breathing of freedom, and of the all‐glorious sentiment of devotion to the cause of universal happiness” (Unsigned review of Friendshipʼs Offering [1830], etc., 437). The boon of Scottishness that Pringle brought to the annual was a perception that it could be played into memory which was upheld by poesy. Barton, Epistle.

div.head: Illustration
div.p: The pictorial “embellishments” of the annuals were as significant as their literary content, if not more so. As the Monthly Review remarked, critical scrutiny of the annuals was justified by their literary content, which, although “fugitive and trifling . . . in some instances”, was worth “the attention of a journal which professes to watch the intellect of the country”; however, it was the annualsʼ pictorial content that placed the annuals in “a class by themselves, which enables us to judge . . . of the progress made amongst us, not only in literary composition, but in the arts” (Unsigned review of Forget Me Not [1829], The Winterʼs Wreath [1829], The Gem [1829], The Literary Souvenir [1829], and Friendshipʼs Offering [1829], 377–78; and see Annuals and Other Illustrated Books: Steel Engraving).

In Friendshipʼs Offering, from Relfeʼs volumes to Smith, Elderʼs, the number of “embellishments” per volume remained twelve or thirteen, including the frontispiece and presentation plate, which form part of the frontmatter. (A presentation plate is an engraved title page with a blank cartouche, in which the giver or owner could inscribe a name or brief message.) Although some annuals competed by offering more embellishments, a dozen or so was typical of other annuals besides Friendshipʼs Offering, presumably because the number of plates was limited not only by the expense of commissioning artists and engravers but also by the availability of space between text signatures for insertion of plates. While the number of plates remained steady over the life of Friendshipʼs Offering, some differing phases can be detected in approaches to the Sister Arts, and in tastes of the times and editors. (The following account remains in process.)

div.head: The Poetry of the Sister Arts in the Relfe Annual
div.p: Relfeʼs 1826 volume is instructive in its pairings of picture and poem, which reflect the English Romantic‐era transformation of the ut pictura poesis aesthetic, when the worn pictorialism of the eighteenth century was abandoned in favor of a view of the Sister Arts as “twin facets of a unified poetic experience” (Park, “‘Ut Pictura Poesis’: The Nineteenth‐Century Aftermath”, 156). A shared poetic experience is testified by ekphrastic poems in volume 26, as in a poem accompanying a Claudeʼs Landscape with the Marriage of Isaac and Rebecca (1648, acquired for the National Gallery in 1824, as part of the Angerstein Collection). The speaker declines to engage in rivalry with the painter—the contest of the Renaissance paragone—instead proffering a shared poetic language: “I feel / No envy of thy noble art, / . . . which, unto outward sense, / Speaks in a language so refined” (Bernard Barton, “‘Am I, Too, in Arcadia?’”, in Hervey, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1826], 47–48).

In the same volume, an engraving evoking the art of painting—Honors Rendered to Raphael on his Deathbed (1806), based on a work by the French painter in the Troubadour style, Pierre Nolasque Bergeret (1782–1863)—called for a response unifying the Sister Arts by the poet, L.E.L: despite the “face of death” imprinted on the figure of Raphael, which is “paler and colder than the marble bust”, the poet looks to the artistʼs “soul”, which remains undiminished, “leav[ing] its influence on the heart!” (L.E.L., “Raphaelʼs Death‐Bed”, in Hervey, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1826], 73–75). The shared poetic emotion plays into the memorializing that is stock‐in‐trade of the literary and artistic annual

The unifying poetic emotion of the Sister Arts was especially associated with the artist commissioned for the frontispiece, Richard Westall (1765–1836), known for his illustrations of Romantic‐era poetry and his evocative portraits of Byron. As an 1824 tribute to Westall effused, he was an ideal portraitist of Byron since “Thou sawʼst the poet, with a poetʼs eye, / And hence a poetʼs mind could well descry, / For thou, to graphic genius not confinʼd, / Canʼst boast the powʼrs of a poetic mind” (John Taylor [1757–1832], “Lines on the Portrait of the Late Lord Byron, Painted by Richard Westall, Esq. RA”, quoted in Westall, “Richard Westallʼs Labours of Love”, 60). In this case, the artistʼs poetic reputation perhaps counted for more with readers than the intrinsic merit of his illustrations, which were feeble for this volume.

div.head: A Reflection of the Contest between the British Picturesque Aesthetic and French Neoclassicism
div.p: Besides participating in the “poetic” discourse of the Sister Arts that was typical of the period, the volume for 1826 also reflects a current controversy between British and French aesthetics. While the influence of this debate over the annualʼs commissions may have been adventitious, a signal outcome was the valumeʼs beautiful final plate, based on Rouen, View from Bon‐Secours by Richard Parkes Bonington (1802–28) (see Noon, Richard Parkes Bonington: The Complete Paintings, 121 [no. 57]). Not only is this vedute an instance of rebellious Romantic French artistsʼ advocacy of British picturesque style; it is also, as advertised on the plate, an engraving on steel, thus placing Friendshipʼs Offering in the vanguard of a technological development that had been introduced only in the previous year by Ackermannʼs Forget Me Not for 1825, and that was more famously featured in the current year by Alaric Wattsʼs rival Literary Souvenir for 1826 (see Annuals and Other Illustrated Books: Steel Engraving). Wattsʼs volume presented a steel‐engraved view of the Thames by Turner, Richmond Hill, which, like Boningtonʼs view of the Seine, pictured a river prospect from a high vantage. The rivalry between the annuals thus reflected the aspirations of the young French Romantic artists who, at just this time, were visiting London to study the modern British landscape school.

R. P. Bonington, the son of an émigré British artist from Nottingham living in France, received his training in the atelier of Baron Antoine‐Jean Gros (1771–1835). To a neoclassicist such as Gros and the influential artist and critic Étienne Delécluze (1781–1863), subjects that especially attracted Bonington—the coastal scenery of Normandy and the Gothic architecture of Rouen—seemed random and meaningless, low on the scale of the traditional ordering of the Sister Arts. Studentsʼ understanding should be elevated by historical and religious subjects rather than by landscape—much less by the localized, provincial scenes that characterized the British school, rather than the timeless classical landscapes of the French tradition. Yet, to the alarm of those who defended the tradition of Grosʼs teacher, Jacques‐Louis David (1748–1825), British‐influenced picturesque subjects were gaining popularity in France. French critics also rejected the loose style of the British school, such as the textured brushstrokes of oils by John Constable, and the tonal rather than linear definition of architectural drawing by Samuel Prout and others of the “Monro School”. (Bonington almost certainly encountered Prout personally in Normandy and in Paris.) The seeming disregard for finish by British painters violated the priority that neoclassicism awarded to disegno, the conceptual emphasis on design, line, and form (Noon, Richard Parkes Bonington: The Complete Paintings, 14–18; Noon, Richard Parkes Bonington: The Complete Drawings, 9, 12).

Nonetheless, English style had recently gained impetus in France from the success of Constable, Copley Fielding, and other British painters at the Paris Salon of 1824. Fired by enthusiasm for British landscape art and for the naturalistic approach it represented, Bonington visited London in 1825, in the company of Alexandre‐Marie Colin (1798–1875), Eugène Delacroix (1798–1863), and other young French artists in the vanguard of French Romanticism. For his contacts in London, Bonington relied on engravers, including the Cooke family, known for their reproduction of work by J. M. W. Turner (Noon, Richard Parkes Bonington: The Complete Paintings, 34–35). It was a younger member of that family, William John Cooke (1796–1865), who was responsible for engraving Boningtonʼs Rouen on steel—the technology that made mass production of pictures in the annuals practicable. Cooke brought state‐of‐the‐art skill to the commission, earning a medal in 1826 for his improvements in etching steel (Hunnisett, Steel‐engraved Book Illustration in England, 48–49; Munday, Edward William Cooke, 37–38).
Ironically, as presented in the respective annuals, the French‐English affiliations behind Boningtonʼs and Turnerʼs river scenes are turned into rivalries

In volume 26 of Friendshipʼs Offering, figure compositions by French artists likewise reflected the current tensions between neoclassicism and Romanticism. In two plates based on paintings by Horace Vernet (1789–1863), The Dog of the Regiment and The Dead Trumpeter, battlefield scenes are combined with genre subjects highlighting the loyalty of domestic animals amid the carnage of war. From the standpoint of the critic Delécluze, Vernetʼs Salon pictures, on which engravings like these were based, represented a confusion of genre and history painting, threatening the conceptual basis of grande peinture (Doyle, “Bad Manners vs. Good Maniera”, 140). Worse, Vernet disseminated a taste for such mixed subjects by embracing contemporary forms of art reproduction, such as lithography and aquatint, which challenged the authority given to line engraving by the French Academy (Bann, “Horace Vernet and Paul Delaroche”, 230–31; and on the broader context of these debates see Noon, Richard Parkes Bonington: The Complete Paintings, 24–30). In Friendshipʼs Offering, however, the genre elements in Vernetʼs pictures are brought forward by T. K. Herveyʼs poems, which construct memories of home for fallen masters of the forlorn animals.

Overall, volume 26 of Friendshipʼs Offering would have been regarded by a traditionalist French critic as representative of how the commercialization of art through book illustration, and through such popular spectacles as the diorama, threatened a degeneration of the ideology propping up the traditional ordering of the arts. Even the volumeʼs single example approaching Davidian neoclassicism (softened by color and eroticism), Aeneas Tells Dido the Misfortunes of the City of Troy, originated with Pierre‐Narcisse Guérin (1774–1833), Vernetʼs friend and predecessor as director of the Académie de France à Rome. The English writer for the Monthly Review considered Guérinʼs Aeneas “cold and stiff”, but singled out Vernetʼs genre vignettes as “really . . . beautiful little piece[s]”, which did “great credit” to the engraver, Edward Finden, as did the “clever” plate of Rouen engraved by Cooke (Unsigned review of Friendshipʼs Offering [1826] and Janus [1826], 165). Fixated on print technologies, the Monthly Review sometimes identified only the engravers, and not the artists, of plates in the annuals, as in the review of Friendshipʼs Offering for 1827 (p. 87).

div.head: “Made Expressly for the Work”: The Art Scene in the Smith, Elder Annual
div.p: See Smith, Elder, & Company for the firmʼs ambitious early publications in engraving and aquatint. According to an early biographer of the firm, Leonard Huxley, art reproduction was the special care of Alexander Elder (1790–1876), who was interested in art (House of Smith Elder, 10). Presumably, Elder would have been anxious to showcase the firmʼs expertise in their selection and presentation of the new annualʼs embellishments. The firm would also have needed to extend their expertise beyond engraving and aquatint to commission steel engraving (see Annuals and Other Illustrated Books: Steel Engraving).

As at least an appearance of shift in emphasis, Smith, Elder advertised that their debut volume would feature engravings taken from recently exhibited British paintings, including art “painted expressly for the Work”. The frontispiece for 1828, A Sylph, reproduced a painting “exhibited at Somerset House, in 1827”—that is in the Royal Academy exhibiting rooms (engraved by William Humphrys [1794–1865]; Knight, ed., “The Friendshipʼs Offering, for 1828” [advertisement]). The artist was a history painter, John Wood (1801–70), who had recently gained recognition at the Royal Academy for such works as Psyche Conveyed by Zephyrs to the Valley of Pleasure (1826; Sir John Soaneʼs Museum, London; see Cooper, “Wood, John [1801–1870]”). In the following volume, for 1829, Wood created a frontispiece “expressly for this work”, Psyche and Cupid (engraved by Edward Finden; Pringle, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1829], viii).

Woodʼs mildly erotic fancy pictures of classical subjects were not exclusive to Friendshipʼs Offering, and his work continued to occupy frontispieces and other placements in Friendshipʼs Offering for 1830 and afterward, without necessarily being puffed as “made expressly”. Albeit an exaggeration, the decision by Smith, Elder to feature pictures from recent London exhibitions spoke to the attention that reviewers gave to annuals as a measure of “the intellect of the country”. The same justification, it seems, lay behind the decision to give equal weight, in the list of embellishments for 1830, to the identification “in the collection of” as to “made expressly for” and “as exhibited at”—the patronage of collectors standing also as a measure of nationʼs intellect and wealth. For consumers like the Ruskins, studying the plates and their accompanying ekphrastic poems and essays raised their awareness of London exhibiting institutions and poetic tropes for responding to modern works.

div.head: Pringleʼs Scottish Landscapes
div.p: For 1829, several embellishments reflect the Scottish emphasis that Pringle summmoned in the literary contributions (see The Pringle Editorship). Following Woodʼs frontispiece, which both dignifies and feminizes the volume using a classical subject, other plates pivot to landscape, introduced early and prominently with Glen‐Lynden, a “landscape with ruins, designed and engraved for this work by John Martin”. In 1829, Martin (1789–1854) stood at the height of his fame for his panoramic paintings of apocalyptic biblical events; and since 1826, he had been producing from his own studio the large mezzotints on steel that extended the audience for his popular paintings, such as the prints Joshua Commanding the Sun to Stand Still (1827; painting first exhibited 1816); and The Deluge (1828; painting first exhibited 1826). At the same time, Martin was designing and producing small mezzotints for the annuals, publishing over twenty plates between 1826 and 1837 in the Amulet, the Literary Souvenir, and other annuals. Among the earliest of these small prints was Glen‐Lynden for Friendshipʼs Offering (Wees, “Darkness Visible”, 3, 29–30, 33 [cat. no. 24]).

Rendered in Martinʼs sublime style, Glen‐Lynden overwhelms its homely pairing, the poem “Glen‐Lynden: A Tale of Teviotdale” by the volume editor, whose persona humbles himself as the “last and lowliest of the train” of poets to pay “pious tribute” to “haunted Teviot”, “the loved mother he has left behind”. Since his early “Autumnal Excursion” (1819), Pringle preferred the traditional name Teviotdale for the valley of the Teviot River near Kelso in Roxburghshire, where he was born. The name Glen Lynden, although used here for a fictional Border glen, was in real life the name Pringle bestowed on the settlement in Cape Colony (Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 79). In the posthumous edition of Pringleʼs poems, “Glen‐Lynden” would be re‐presented as a fragment of “The Emigrants” intended to incorporate a fictionalized account of the immigration to South Africa. Standing alone, “Glen Lynden” could “call to mind / The scenes that Scottish hearts to their dear country bind” even for those in “foreign lands” only as far as England like the Ruskins (Pringle, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1829], 19).

As if designed as a melancholy reminder specifically for the Ruskin family, the theme of Scottish landscape with ruins continues in volume 29 with Campbell Castle, drawn by George Arnald (1763–1841), supported by a poem by David Macbeth Moir (“Delta”, 1798–1851) (Pringle, ed., Friendshipʼs Offering [1829], 143–44). The castle is located in the Ochil Hills, which the Ruskins passed through in their journeys north to visit the family of John Jamesʼs sister, Jessie Richardson, in Perth—journeys now curtailed by the deaths of Jessie and two of her children in 1826–28 (See note on Glenfarg).

div.head: Binding
div.p: The success of Smith, Elderʼs takeover of Friendshipʼs Offering hinged in part on a daring innovation in binding, which substituted full calf for the printed paper‐covered boards that was typical of many annuals, including Forget‐Me‐Not. The calf binding was blind‐embossed on the full surface of both front and back covers with an arabesque design, and with a lyre design blocked in gilt in the center of the front cover. As Eleanore Jamieson explains in “The Binding Styles of the Gift Books and Annuals” (p. 11), the arabesque pattern was regarded as a revival style hearkening to incunabula, and the style was associated with Continental models (see also Annuals and Other Illustrated Books: Bindings).

The annuals dueled to be judged by their covers, the Ackermann firmʼs Forget Me Not having set an initial standard with its printed and glazed paper boards, cloth spine, and slipcase, later replaced by a silk cover (Ford, Ackermann, 65). Innovation and extravagance—or at least the appearance of extravagance—in bindings and engraved or lithographed front matter became characteristic of annuals, which used this immediate source of appeal to compete in a crowded market (see Faxon, Literary Annuals, xiv–xvi). Mechanization brought these material appeals within reach of the ordinary consumer; and mass‐produced fancy bindings in particular shifted traditional division of labor, since publishers took on the economic burden of bookbinding, which conventionally had been borne by the consumer.

Harris also speculates that the annualʼs elaborately embossed leather covers suggested the bindings of prayer books and bibles—the only other expensively bound stock that retailers typically offered over the counter (as opposed to cheap temporary bindings, to be replaced by the consumer). These “gospel‐like bindings” may have been meant “to convince the reading public of the wholesome value of the literature and engravings within” (Harris, Forget Me Not, 131, 133–34). A perception of wholesomeness may be borne out by a favorable notice of the 1829 volume in The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction, which focused first on the “exterior, which is somewhat novel in taste, . . . by substituting for the usual paper covering [i.e., like the printed paper boards then covering the Forget Me Not], an elegantly embossed leather binding. This is altogether an improvement on the original plan, since the slight coverings of silk or paper is scarcely safe out of the drawing‐room or boudoir, and some of the contributions to the ‘annuals’ entitle them to a higher stand” (“Spirit of ‘The Annuals’ for 1828”, 418). By the “original plan”, the writer refers apparently to the binding used by Relfe, which consisted of glazed paper boards, printed with a decorative and typographic cover, in imitation of the binding used for the Forget Me Not, but he also refers to the silk covering already being adopted by Forget Me Not (see Harris, Forget Me Not, 133). The comment apparently gestures at an audience expanded beyond the “boudoir” to include male readers along with the entire family.

According to a review of the first Smith, Elder volume, for 1828, it was “for the gratification of different tastes”, however, that “the colour . . . [was] varied” (“The Annuals for 1828”, 193). Maroon is the most common color found among surviving copies today, suggesting that most consumers chose an appearance of respectability; however, a brighter red and possibly a green can still be found as well.
